                "contents": "/**\n * Start the WebSocket server\n */\nasync function startServer(options: Record<string, string | boolean>): Promise<void> {\n  try {\n    // Load configuration\n    const configPath = typeof options.config === 'string' ? options.config : undefined;\n    const config: ReverbConfig = await loadConfig(configPath);\n\n    // Get server configuration (use 'reverb' as default server name)\n    const serverName = config.default || 'reverb';\n    const serverConfig = config.servers[serverName];\n\n    if (!serverConfig) {\n      console.error(`❌ Server configuration not found for: ${serverName}`);\n      process.exit(1);\n    }\n\n    // Override with CLI options\n    const host = (typeof options.host === 'string' ? options.host : undefined) || serverConfig.host;\n    const port = (typeof options.port === 'string' ? options.port : undefined) || String(serverConfig.port);\n    const path = (typeof options.path === 'string' ? options.path : undefined) || serverConfig.path || '';\n    const hostname = (typeof options.hostname === 'string' ? options.hostname : undefined) || serverConfig.hostname;\n    const maxRequestSize = serverConfig.max_request_size || 10000;\n    const serverOptions = serverConfig.options || {};\n\n    // Log configuration\n    console.log('🚀 Starting Revurb WebSocket Server');\n    console.log('');\n    console.log('Configuration:');\n    console.log(`  Host:     ${host}`);\n    console.log(`  Port:     ${port}`);\n    if (path) {\n      console.log(`  Path:     ${path}`);\n    }\n    if (hostname && hostname !== host) {\n      console.log(`  Hostname: ${hostname}`);\n    }\n    console.log(`  Protocol: pusher`);\n    console.log('');\n\n    // Log applications\n    const apps = config.apps.apps || [];\n    console.log(`Applications: ${apps.length}`);\n    for (const app of apps) {\n      console.log(`  - ${app.app_id} (key: ${app.key})`);\n    }\n    console.log('');\n\n    // Initialize factory with configuration\n    Factory.initialize(config);\n\n    // Setup event listeners for observability\n    setupEventListeners(options.debug === true);\n\n    // Create and start server\n    const server = Factory.make\n;\n}",

                },
                "contents": "export class Factory {\n\n\n  /**\n   * Handle WebSocket connection requests\n   *\n   * @param req - The incoming request\n   * @param params - Route parameters including appKey\n   * @param server - The Bun server instance for WebSocket upgrades\n   * @returns Response with WebSocket upgrade or error, or undefined for successful upgrade\n   *\n   * @private\n   */\n  private static handleWebSocketConnection(req: Request, params: Record<string, string>, server?: any): Response | undefined {\n    // Check if this is a WebSocket upgrade request\n    if (req.headers.get('upgrade') !== 'websocket') {\n      return new Response('Expected WebSocket upgrade', { status: 400 });\n    }\n\n    if (!server) {\n      return new Response('Server instance not available', { status: 500 });\n    }\n\n    if (!this.appManager || !this.pusherServer) {\n      return new Response('Server not initialized. Call Factory.initialize() first.', { status: 500 });\n    }\n\n    const appKey = params.appKey;\n    if (!appKey) {\n      return new Response('Missing app key', { status: 400 });\n    }\n\n    // Find application by key\n    let app: Application | null = null;\n    try {\n      const provider = this.appManager.driver();\n      app = provider.findByKey(appKey);\n    } catch (error) {\n      console.error('Error finding application:', error);\n      return new Response('Invalid application', { status: 404 });\n    }\n\n    if (!app) {\n      return new Response('Application not found', { status: 404 });\n    }\n\n    // Get origin from request\n    const origin = req.headers.get('origin');\n\n    // Set up WebSocket data with app and origin for use in handlers\n    const wsData: WebSocketData = {\n      app,\n      origin,\n    };\n\n    // Upgrade the connection to WebSocket\n    const upgraded = server.upgrade(req, {\n      data: wsData,\n    });\n\n    if (!upgraded) {\n      return new Response('WebSocket upgrade failed', { status: 500 });\n    }\n\n    // Return undefined to indicate successful upgrade (Bun requirement)\n    // The actual connection handling will happen in the websocket.open handler\n    return undefined;\n  }\n\n  /**\n   * Handle event triggering\n   *\n   * @param req - The incoming request\n   * @param params - Route parameters including appId\n   * @returns JSON response with result\n   *\n   * @private\n   */\n}",

                    "line": 342,

                },
                "contents": "export class Server {\n\n\n  /**\n   * Determine if a request should be upgraded to WebSocket.\n   *\n   * Checks if the request is a WebSocket upgrade request and if the path\n   * is one that should be handled as a WebSocket connection.\n   *\n   * @param pathname - The request path\n   * @param req - The incoming HTTP request\n   * @returns true if the request should be upgraded to WebSocket\n   *\n   * @private\n   */\n  private shouldUpgradeToWebSocket(pathname: string, req: Request): boolean {\n    // Check if this is a WebSocket upgrade request\n    const upgrade = req.headers.get('upgrade')?.toLowerCase();\n    if (upgrade !== 'websocket') {\n      return false;\n    }\n\n    // WebSocket connections typically use these paths\n    return pathname === '/app' || pathname.startsWith('/app/');\n  }\n\n  /**\n   * Handle WebSocket connection opened event.\n   *\n   * Called when a new WebSocket connection is successfully established.\n   * This is where application-level connection setup would occur.\n   *\n   * @param ws - The WebSocket connection\n   *\n   * @private\n   */\n}",

                "contents": "function loadAppsConfig(): AppsConfig {\n\n}\n\n/**\n * Load the complete Reverb configuration from environment variables or config file\n *\n * This function reads all necessary environment variables and constructs\n * a complete ReverbConfig object with sensible defaults matching the PHP\n * Laravel configuration.\n *\n * If a configPath is provided, it will attempt to load and merge that configuration\n * with environment variables (env vars take precedence).\n *\n * Required environment variables:\n * - REVERB_APP_KEY: Application key for authentication\n * - REVERB_APP_SECRET: Application secret for authentication\n * - REVERB_APP_ID: Application ID\n *\n * Optional environment variables (with defaults):\n * - REVERB_SERVER (default: 'reverb')\n * - REVERB_SERVER_HOST (default: '0.0.0.0')\n * - REVERB_SERVER_PORT (default: 8080)\n * - REVERB_SERVER_PATH (default: '')\n * - REVERB_HOST (default: undefined)\n * - REVERB_MAX_REQUEST_SIZE (default: 10000)\n * - REVERB_SCALING_ENABLED (default: false)\n * - REVERB_SCALING_CHANNEL (default: 'reverb')\n * - REDIS_URL (default: undefined)\n * - REDIS_HOST (default: '127.0.0.1')\n * - REDIS_PORT (default: '6379')\n * - REDIS_USERNAME (default: undefined)\n * - REDIS_PASSWORD (default: undefined)\n * - REDIS_DB (default: '0')\n * - REDIS_TIMEOUT (default: 60)\n * - REVERB_PULSE_INGEST_INTERVAL (default: 15)\n * - REVERB_TELESCOPE_INGEST_INTERVAL (default: 15)\n * - REVERB_PORT (default: 443)\n * - REVERB_SCHEME (default: 'https')\n * - REVERB_APP_PING_INTERVAL (default: 60)\n * - REVERB_APP_ACTIVITY_TIMEOUT (default: 30)\n * - REVERB_APP_MAX_CONNECTIONS (default: undefined)\n * - REVERB_APP_MAX_MESSAGE_SIZE (default: 10000)\n * - REVERB_ALLOWED_ORIGINS (default: '*', comma-separated)\n *\n * @param configPath - Optional path to a configuration file to load\n * @throws {Error} If required environment variables are not set\n * @returns The complete Reverb configuration\n */\nexport async function loadConfig(configPath?: string): Promise<ReverbConfig> {\n  const defaultServer = env('REVERB_SERVER', 'reverb')!;\n\n  // Determine which config file to load\n  // Priority: 1. Explicit configPath, 2. ./reverb.config.ts, 3. Environment only\n  let fileToLoad = configPath;\n  if (!fileToLoad) {\n    // Check for default config file in current working directory\n    try {\n      // Use Bun's file system to check if file exists\n      const defaultConfigPath = './reverb.config.ts';\n      const file = Bun.file(defaultConfigPath);\n      if (await file.exists()) {\n        // Resolve to absolute path for reliable import\n        fileToLoad = resolve(process.cwd(), 'reverb.config.ts');\n      }\n    } catch {\n      // File doesn't exist, that's fine - we'll use env config only\n      fileToLoad = undefined;\n    }\n  }\n\n  // If a config file path is determined, try to load and merge it\n  if (fileToLoad) {\n    try {\n      // For absolute paths, use file:// protocol for ES module import\n      // For relative paths provided by user, use as-is\n      const importPath = fileToLoad.startsWith('/')\n        ? `file://${fileToLoad}`\n        : fileToLoad;\n      const fileConfig = await import(importPath);\n      const config = fileConfig.default || fileConfig;\n\n      // Build server config from environment (always needed)\n      const envServerConfig: ReverbConfig = {\n        default: defaultServer,\n        servers: {\n          [defaultServer]: loadReverbServerConfig(),\n        },\n        apps: {\n          provider: 'config',\n          apps: [],\n        },\n      };\n\n      // Try to load apps from environment, but don't fail if they're missing\n      // when a config file is provided - merge/append instead\n      let envApps: ReverbAppConfig[] = [];\n      try {\n        const envAppsConfig = loadAppsConfig();\n        envApps = envAppsConfig.apps;\n      } catch (error) {\n        // If env vars are missing, that's fine - we'll use config file apps only\n        // This allows config-driven deployments without requiring REVERB_APP_* vars\n      }\n\n      // Merge configs - env vars take precedence for servers, but append apps\n      return {\n        ...config,\n        default: envServerConfig.default,\n        servers: {\n          ...config.servers,\n          ...envServerConfig.servers,\n        },\n        apps: {\n          provider:\n}",

                "contents": "export class Factory {\npublic static make(\n    host: string = '0.0.0.0',\n    port: string = '8080',\n    path: string = '',\n    hostname?: string,\n    maxRequestSize: number = 10000,\n    options: HttpServerOptions = {},\n    protocol: string = 'pusher',\n    environment: string = process.env.NODE_ENV || 'development',\n  ) {\nconst serveOptions: ServeOptions & { maxRequestBodySize?: number } = {\n(ws: any) => {\n\n            ws.close();\n          }\n        },\n        message: (ws: any, message: string | Buffer) => {\n          // WebSocket message handler\n          const data = ws.data as WebSocketData | undefined;\n          if (!data?.connection) {\n            console.error('WebSocket message received without connection');\n            return;\n          }\n\n          try {\n            const messageStr = typeof message === 'string' ? message : message.toString('utf-8');\n\n            // Pass message to Pusher server\n            if (this.pusherServer) {\n              this.pusherServer.message(data.connection, messageStr);\n            }\n          } catch (error) {\n            console.error('Error handling WebSocket message:', error);\n          }\n        },\n        close: (ws: any) => {\n          // WebSocket close handler\n          const data = ws.data as WebSocketData | undefined;\n          if (!data?.connection) {\n            return;\n          }\n\n          try {\n            // Notify Pusher server of connection close\n            if (this.pusherServer) {\n              this.pusherServer.close(data.connection);\n            }\n          } catch (error) {\n            console.error('Error closing WebSocket connection:', error);\n          }\n        },\n        ping: (ws: any) => {\n          // Ping handler\n          const data = ws.data as WebSocketData | undefined;\n          if (!data?.connection) {\n            return;\n          }\n\n          try {\n            // Create PING frame and pass to Pusher server\n            if (this.pusherServer) {\n              this.pusherServer.control(data.connection, {\n                opcode: 0x9 as any,\n                payload: '',\n                getContents: () => '',\n              });\n            }\n          } catch (error) {\n            console.error('Error handling ping:', error);\n          }\n        },\n        pong: (ws: any) => {\n          // Pong handler\n          const data = ws.data as WebSocketData | undefined;\n        }\n,\n    };\n  }\n}",

                "contents": "export class Server {\n\n\n  /**\n   * Start the HTTP server.\n   *\n   * Initializes Bun.serve() with the configured port, host, and handlers.\n   * Sets up periodic garbage collection and error handling.\n   * The server will accept both HTTP and WebSocket connections.\n   *\n   * @throws Will log errors but not throw directly; error handling is done\n   *         through the logger interface\n   */\n  start(): void {\n    try {\n      const config: any = {\n        port: this.config.port,\n        hostname: this.config.host,\n        fetch: (req: Request, server: any) => this.handleRequest(req, server),\n        websocket: {\n          open: (ws: any) => this.handleWebSocketOpen(ws),\n          message: (ws: any, message: string | Buffer) => this.handleWebSocketMessage(ws, message),\n          close: (ws: any, code: number, reason: string) => this.handleWebSocketClose(ws, code, reason),\n          ping: (ws: any, data: Buffer) => this.handleWebSocketPing(ws, data),\n          pong: (ws: any, data: Buffer) => this.handleWebSocketPong(ws, data),\n        },\n      };\n\n      // Only add TLS if it's defined (not null or undefined)\n      if (this.config.tls) {\n        config.tls = this.config.tls;\n      }\n\n      this.bunServer = Bun.serve(config);\n\n      this.isRunning = true;\n\n      // Set up periodic garbage collection every 30 seconds\n      this.gcTimer = setInterval(() => {\n        if (typeof gc !== 'undefined') {\n          // Note: gc.collect() may not be available in all Bun versions\n          (gc as any).collect?.();\n        }\n      }, 30_000);\n\n      this.config.logger.info('Server started', `Listening on ${this.config.host}:${this.config.port}`);\n    } catch (error) {\n      const message = error instanceof Error ? error.message : String(error);\n      this.config.logger.error(message);\n      this.isRunning = false;\n    }\n  }\n\n  /**\n   * Stop the HTTP server.\n   *\n   * Gracefully shuts down the server, stops garbage collection,\n   * and closes all connections.\n   */\n}",

                "contents": "/**\n * Load Reverb server configuration from environment variables\n *\n * @returns The Reverb server configuration\n */\nfunction loadReverbServerConfig(): ReverbServerConfig {\n  const path = env('REVERB_SERVER_PATH', '');\n  const hostname = env('REVERB_HOST');\n  const options = loadServerOptions();\n  const max_request_size = envInt('REVERB_MAX_REQUEST_SIZE', 10000);\n  const scaling = loadScalingConfig();\n  const pulse_ingest_interval = envInt('REVERB_PULSE_INGEST_INTERVAL', 15);\n  const telescope_ingest_interval = envInt('REVERB_TELESCOPE_INGEST_INTERVAL', 15);\n\n  return {\n    host: env('REVERB_SERVER_HOST', '0.0.0.0')!,\n    port: envInt('REVERB_SERVER_PORT', 8080),\n    ...(path !== undefined ? { path } : {}),\n    ...(hostname !== undefined ? { hostname } : {}),\n    ...(options !== undefined ? { options } : {}),\n    ...(max_request_size !== undefined ? { max_request_size } : {}),\n    ...(scaling !== undefined ? { scaling } : {}),\n    ...(pulse_ingest_interval !== undefined ? { pulse_ingest_interval } : {}),\n    ...(telescope_ingest_interval !== undefined ? { telescope_ingest_interval } : {}),\n  };\n}\n\n/**\n * Load application connection options from environment variables\n *\n * @returns The application connection options\n */",

                "contents": "export class Factory {\n\n\n  /**\n   * Create a new router for the Pusher protocol\n   *\n   * Sets up all routes required for Pusher protocol support.\n   * This includes WebSocket connections and HTTP API endpoints.\n   *\n   * @param path - URL path prefix for all routes\n   * @returns Router - Configured router instance\n   *\n   * @private\n   */\n  private static makePusherRouter(path: string): Router {\n    const router = new Router();\n\n    // Set up Pusher routes with optional path prefix\n    const routes = this.pusherRoutes(path);\n\n    for (const route of routes) {\n      if (route.method === 'GET') {\n        router.get(route.path, route.handler);\n      } else if (route.method === 'POST') {\n        router.post(route.path, route.handler);\n      }\n    }\n\n    return router;\n  }\n\n  /**\n   * Generate the routes required to handle Pusher protocol requests\n   *\n   * Defines all HTTP API endpoints for:\n   * - WebSocket connections\n   * - Event triggering\n   * - Connection management\n   * - Channel information\n   * - Health checks\n   *\n   * @param path - URL path prefix for all routes\n   * @returns Array of route definitions\n   *\n   * @private\n   */\n}",

                  "endPosition": {
                    "line": 342,
                    "column": 1
                  }
                },
                "contents": "export class Server {\n\n\n  /**\n   * Handle incoming HTTP requests.\n   *\n   * Routes HTTP requests and handles WebSocket upgrades.\n   * For WebSocket upgrades, this delegates to Bun's upgrade mechanism.\n   * For regular HTTP requests, this routes to the router for application logic.\n   *\n   * @param req - The incoming HTTP request\n   * @param server - The Bun server instance (used for WebSocket upgrades)\n   * @returns A Response object for the request\n   *\n   * @private\n   */\n  private async handleRequest(req: Request, server: any): Promise<Response | undefined> {\n    const url = new URL(req.url);\n    const pathname = url.pathname;\n\n    // Attempt WebSocket upgrade for specific paths\n    if (this.shouldUpgradeToWebSocket(pathname, req)) {\n      if (server.upgrade(req)) {\n        return undefined;\n      }\n    }\n\n    // Route HTTP requests\n    try {\n      // For HTTP requests, pass null as connection since we don't have a Connection object yet\n      const result = await this.config.router.dispatch(req as any, null as any);\n\n      // If result is already a Response, return it\n      if (result instanceof Response) {\n        return result;\n      }\n\n      // Otherwise, wrap result in a Response\n      return new Response(JSON.stringify(result), {\n        status: 200,\n        headers: { 'content-type': 'application/json' },\n      });\n    } catch (error) {\n      if (error instanceof HttpException) {\n        return new Response(error.message, {\n          status: error.statusCode,\n          headers: { 'content-type': 'text/plain' },\n        });\n      }\n\n      const message = error instanceof Error ? error.message : 'Internal server error';\n      this.config.logger.error(message);\n\n      return new Response('Internal server error', {\n        status: 500,\n        headers: { 'content-type': 'text/plain' },\n      });\n    }\n  }\n\n  /**\n   * Determine if a request should be upgraded to WebSocket.\n   *\n   * Checks if the request is a WebSocket upgrade request and if the path\n   * is one that should be handled as a WebSocket connection.\n   *\n   * @param pathname - The request path\n   * @param req - The incoming HTTP request\n   * @returns true if the request should be upgraded to WebSocket\n   *\n   * @private\n   */\n}",

                },
                "contents": "export class Router {\n\n\n  /**\n   * Negotiate the WebSocket connection upgrade (RFC 6455 Handshake)\n   *\n   * This method implements the WebSocket opening handshake as defined in RFC 6455:\n   * 1. Generates the Sec-WebSocket-Accept header using SHA-1 hash\n   * 2. Creates the upgrade response with required headers\n   * 3. Sends the response to the client\n   * 4. Wraps the raw connection in a ReverbConnection\n   *\n   * @see https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6455#section-4\n   *\n   * @param request - The HTTP request object\n   * @param connection - The raw socket connection\n   * @returns A new ReverbConnection instance for WebSocket communication\n   *\n   * @private\n   */\n  private attemptUpgrade(request: IHttpRequest, connection: Connection): any {\n    // Get the Sec-WebSocket-Key from the request\n    const secWebSocketKey = request.getHeader('sec-websocket-key');\n\n    if (!secWebSocketKey) {\n      this.close(connection, 400, 'Missing Sec-WebSocket-Key header.');\n      throw new Error('WebSocket upgrade failed: missing Sec-WebSocket-Key');\n    }\n\n    // Generate the accept key using RFC 6455 algorithm\n    const acceptKey = this.generateAcceptKey(secWebSocketKey);\n\n    // Build the upgrade response\n    const statusLine = 'HTTP/1.1 101 Switching Protocols\\r\\n';\n    const headers = [\n      'Upgrade: websocket',\n      'Connection: Upgrade',\n      `Sec-WebSocket-Accept: ${acceptKey}`,\n      'X-Powered-By: Reverb',\n    ];\n\n    const responseHeaders = headers.join('\\r\\n') + '\\r\\n\\r\\n';\n    const upgradeResponse = statusLine + responseHeaders;\n\n    // Send the upgrade response\n    connection.send(upgradeResponse);\n\n    // Return the connection wrapped as a WebSocket connection\n    // In a real implementation, this would wrap the raw connection\n    // For now, return the connection as-is (the actual WebSocket upgrade\n    // would be handled by the underlying socket layer)\n    return connection;\n  }\n\n  /**\n   * Generate the Sec-WebSocket-Accept header value (RFC 6455)\n   *\n   * The accept key is generated by:\n   * 1. Concatenating the client's Sec-WebSocket-Key with the magic GUID\n   * 2. Generating a SHA-1 hash of the concatenated string\n   * 3. Base64 encoding the hash\n   *\n   * @see https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6455#section-4.2.2\n   *\n   * @param secWebSocketKey - The client's Sec-WebSocket-Key header value\n   * @returns The Sec-WebSocket-Accept header value\n   *\n   * @private\n   */\n}",

                "contents": "import type { WebSocket } from \"bun\";\nimport type { IWebSocketConnection, Frame } from \"../../contracts/websocket-connection\";\n\n/**\n * WebSocket Connection Implementation\n *\n * Wraps Bun's native WebSocket to provide the IWebSocketConnection interface.\n * This class handles WebSocket frame operations, message buffering for fragmented messages,\n * and control frame handling according to RFC 6455.\n *\n * Key responsibilities:\n * - Provide unique connection identification\n * - Send text/binary messages over the WebSocket\n * - Send and handle control frames (PING, PONG, CLOSE)\n * - Manage connection lifecycle with proper cleanup\n *\n * Note: Bun's WebSocket handles frame framing automatically, so we focus on\n * providing a consistent API for message handling and control frames.\n */\nexport class Connection implements IWebSocketConnection {\n  /**\n   * Handler for complete messages.\n   */\n  private onMessageHandler?: (message: string | Buffer) => void;\n\n  /**\n   * Handler for connection close.\n   */\n  // @ts-expect-error - Reserved for future use\n  private _onCloseHandler?: () => void;\n\n  /**\n   * Maximum allowed message payload size in bytes.\n   */\n  private maxMessageSize?: number;\n\n  /**\n   * Unique connection identifier.\n   */\n  private connectionId: string;\n\n  /**\n   * Create a new WebSocket connection instance.\n   *\n   * @param socket - The Bun WebSocket instance\n   */\n  constructor(private socket: WebSocket) {\n    // Generate a unique connection ID using the socket's internal data\n    this.connectionId = this.generateConnectionId();\n    // Note: For Bun's server-side WebSockets, handlers are set in serve() options,\n    // not on individual socket objects. We don't need setupHandlers() here.\n  }\n\n  /**\n   * Generate a unique connection identifier.\n   * Uses the socket's remoteAddress and a timestamp for uniqueness.\n   */\n}",

                "contents": "export class Router {\n\n\n  /**\n   * Dispatch the HTTP request to the appropriate controller\n   *\n   * This method:\n   * 1. Matches the request URI to a route\n   * 2. Extracts the controller and route parameters\n   * 3. Handles WebSocket upgrades if requested\n   * 4. Resolves controller parameters from route and request context\n   * 5. Calls the controller with appropriate arguments\n   * 6. Handles HTTP errors (404, 405, 500)\n   *\n   * @param request - The HTTP request object\n   * @param connection - The connection object\n   * @returns The controller response (Promise, string, or any result)\n   *\n   * @throws Will close connection with appropriate HTTP error code if route matching fails\n   */\n  async dispatch(request: IHttpRequest, connection: Connection): Promise<any> {\n    try {\n      // Set up route matcher context\n      this.matcher.setContext({\n        method: request.getMethod(),\n        host: request.getHost(),\n      });\n\n      // Attempt to match the route\n      let route: Record<string, any>;\n      try {\n        route = this.matcher.match(request.getPath());\n      } catch (error) {\n        if (this.isMethodNotAllowedException(error)) {\n          const allowedMethods = this.getAllowedMethods(error);\n          this.close(connection, 405, 'Method not allowed.', { Allow: allowedMethods });\n          return null;\n        }\n\n        if (this.isResourceNotFoundException(error)) {\n          this.close(connection, 404, 'Not found.');\n          return null;\n        }\n\n        throw error;\n      }\n\n      // Get the controller from the route\n      const controller = this.controller(route);\n\n      // Check if this is a WebSocket upgrade request\n      if (this.isWebSocketRequest(request)) {\n        const wsConnection = this.attemptUpgrade(request, connection);\n\n        // Call the controller with websocket connection and route parameters\n        const routeParams = this.extractRouteParams(route);\n        return await controller(request, wsConnection, ...Object.values(routeParams));\n      }\n\n      // For HTTP requests, resolve parameters and call controller\n      const routeParameters = {\n        ...this.extractRouteParams(route),\n        request,\n        connection,\n      };\n\n      const args = this.arguments(controller, routeParameters);\n      const response = await controller(...args);\n\n      // Send response and close connection\n      return this.sendResponse(connection, response);\n    } catch (error) {\n      // Handle unexpected errors\n      this.close(connection, 500, 'Internal server error.');\n      throw error;\n    }\n  }\n\n  /**\n   * Get the controller callable for the given route\n   *\n   * @param route - The matched route object\n   * @returns The controller function/callback\n   *\n   * @private\n   */\n}",

                "contents": "export class PusherController {\n\n\n  /**\n   * Invoke the Reverb WebSocket server.\n   *\n   * Handles the initialization of a WebSocket connection for the Pusher protocol.\n   * This method:\n   * 1. Validates the connection and looks up the application\n   * 2. Configures the connection with the application's max message size\n   * 3. Registers event handlers for messages, control frames, and close events\n   * 4. Opens the connection buffer to begin receiving frames\n   * 5. Notifies the server to open the connection\n   *\n   * @param request - The HTTP request that initiated the WebSocket upgrade\n   * @param connection - The WebSocket connection wrapper\n   * @param appKey - The application key from the request path\n   */\n  __invoke(request: IHttpRequest, connection: Connection, appKey: string): void {\n    const reverbConnection = this.connection(request, connection, appKey);\n\n    if (!reverbConnection) {\n      return;\n    }\n\n    connection.withMaxMessageSize(reverbConnection.app().maxMessageSize());\n\n    connection.onMessage(\n      (message: string | Buffer) => this.server.message(reverbConnection, String(message))\n    );\n\n    connection.onControl(\n      (message: Frame) => this.server.control(reverbConnection, message)\n    );\n\n    connection.onClose(\n      () => this.server.close(reverbConnection)\n    );\n\n    // Note: openBuffer() is not needed in TypeScript implementation\n    // as Bun's WebSocket handles buffering automatically\n\n    this.server.open(reverbConnection);\n  }\n\n  /**\n   * Get the Reverb connection instance for the request.\n   *\n   * Looks up the application by key and creates a new ReverbConnection\n   * with the application context and origin information.\n   *\n   * If the application is not found, sends an error message to the client\n   * and closes the connection.\n   *\n   * @param request - The HTTP request\n   * @param connection - The WebSocket connection wrapper\n   * @param key - The application key\n   * @returns The Reverb connection instance, or null if the application is invalid\n   */\n}",

    <a name="introduction"></a>
    ## Introduction
    
    [Revurb](https://github.com/laravel/reverb) is a TypeScript port of Laravel Reverb, bringing blazing-fast and scalable real-time WebSocket communication to your applications. It runs on Bun runtime and provides seamless integration with applications that need real-time event broadcasting capabilities.
    
    Revurb implements the Pusher protocol, making it compatible with Pusher-compatible clients and Laravel's broadcasting system.

          "beforeFullFileContent": "<!-- https://laravel.com/docs/12.x/reverb.md -->\n# Revurb (TypeScript Port of Laravel Reverb)\n\n- [Introduction](#introduction)\n- [Installation](#installation)\n- [Configuration](#configuration)\n    - [Application Credentials](#application-credentials)\n    - [Allowed Origins](#allowed-origins)\n    - [Additional Applications](#additional-applications)\n    - [SSL](#ssl)\n- [Running the Server](#running-server)\n    - [Debugging](#debugging)\n    - [Restarting](#restarting)\n- [Monitoring](#monitoring)\n- [Running Revurb in Production](#production)\n    - [Open Files](#open-files)\n    - [Event Loop](#event-loop)\n    - [Web Server](#web-server)\n    - [Ports](#ports)\n    - [Process Management](#process-management)\n    - [Scaling](#scaling)\n\n<a name=\"introduction\"></a>\n## Introduction\n\n[Revurb](https://github.com/laravel/reverb) is a TypeScript port of Laravel Reverb, bringing blazing-fast and scalable real-time WebSocket communication to your applications. It runs on Bun runtime and provides seamless integration with applications that need real-time event broadcasting capabilities.\n\nRevurb implements the Pusher protocol, making it compatible with Pusher-compatible clients and Laravel's broadcasting system.\n\n<a name=\"installation\"></a>\n## Installation\n\nYou may install Revurb by cloning the repository and installing dependencies:\n\n```shell\ngit clone <repository-url>\ncd revurb-ts\nbun install\n```\n\nTo build the project:\n\n```shell\nbun run build\n```\n\n<a name=\"configuration\"></a>\n## Configuration\n\nRevurb can be configured using environment variables or a TypeScript configuration file. Configuration is loaded in the following order of precedence:\n\n1. Path specified by `--config` CLI option\n2. Environment variables (`REVERB_*`)\n3. `./reverb.config.ts` file\n4. Built-in defaults\n\n<a name=\"application-credentials\"></a>\n### Application Credentials\n\nIn order to establish a connection to Revurb, a set of Revurb \"application\" credentials must be exchanged between the client and server. These credentials are configured on the server and are used to verify the request from the client. You may define these credentials using the following environment variables:\n\n```bash\nREVERB_APP_ID=my-app-id\nREVERB_APP_KEY=my-app-key\nREVERB_APP_SECRET=my-app-secret\n```\n\nAlternatively, you may configure these in a `reverb.config.ts` file:\n\n```typescript\nexport default {\n  default: 'reverb',\n  servers: {\n    reverb: {\n      host: '0.0.0.0',\n      port: 8080,\n    },\n  },\n  apps: {\n    provider: 'config',\n    apps: [\n      {\n        app_id: 'my-app-id',\n        key: 'my-app-key',\n        secret: 'my-app-secret',\n        allowed_origins: ['*'],\n      },\n    ],\n  },\n};\n```\n\n<a name=\"allowed-origins\"></a>\n### Allowed Origins\n\nYou may also define the origins from which client requests may originate by updating the value of the `allowed_origins` configuration value within the `apps` section of your configuration. Any requests from an origin not listed in your allowed origins will be rejected. You may allow all origins using `*`:\n\n```typescript\napps: {\n  provider: 'config',\n  apps: [\n    {\n      app_id: 'my-app-id',\n      allowed_origins: ['laravel.com'],\n      // ...\n    }\n  ]\n}\n```\n\nOr via environment variable:\n\n```bash\nREVERB_ALLOWED_ORIGINS=laravel.com,example.com\n```\n\n<a name=\"additional-applications\"></a>\n### Additional Applications\n\nTypically, Revurb provides a WebSocket server for a single application. However, it is possible to serve more than one application using a single Revurb installation.\n\nFor example, you may wish to maintain a single Revurb server which provides WebSocket connectivity for multiple applications. This can be achieved by defining multiple `apps` in your configuration file:\n\n```typescript\napps: {\n  provider: 'config',\n  apps: [\n    {\n      app_id: 'my-app-one',\n      key: 'app-one-key',\n      secret: 'app-one-secret',\n      // ...\n    },\n    {\n      app_id: 'my-app-two',\n      key: 'app-two-key',\n      secret: 'app-two-secret',\n      // ...\n    },\n  ],\n}\n```\n\n<a name=\"ssl\"></a>\n### SSL\n\nIn most cases, secure WebSocket connections are handled by the upstream web server (Nginx, etc.) before the request is proxied to your Revurb server.\n\nHowever, it can sometimes be useful, such as during local development, for the Revurb server to handle secure connections directly. You may configure TLS/SSL by providing certificate paths in your configuration file:\n\n```typescript\nservers: {\n  reverb: {\n    host: '0.0.0.0',\n    port: 8080,\n    options: {\n      tls: {\n        cert: '/path/to/cert.pem',\n        key: '/path/to/key.pem',\n        // Optional: passphrase for the key\n        passphrase: 'your-passphrase',\n      },\n    },\n  },\n}\n```\n\nYou may also specify a hostname when starting the server to help with certificate resolution:\n\n```shell\nbun run src/cli.ts start --hostname=\"laravel.test\"\n```\n\n<a name=\"running-server\"></a>\n## Running the Server\n\nThe Revurb server can be started using the CLI:\n\n```shell\nbun run src/cli.ts start\n```\n\nOr if you've built the project:\n\n```shell\nbun run start\n```\n\nYou can also use the built binary directly:\n\n```shell\n./dist/cli.js start\n```\n\nBy default, the Revurb server will be started at `0.0.0.0:8080`, making it accessible from all network interfaces.\n\nIf you need to specify a custom host or port, you may do so via the `--host` and `--port` options when starting the server:\n\n```shell\nbun run src/cli.ts start --host=127.0.0.1 --port=9000\n```\n\nYou can also specify a custom configuration file:\n\n```shell\nbun run src/cli.ts start --config=./custom.config.ts\n```\n\nAlternatively, you may define `REVERB_SERVER_HOST` and `REVERB_SERVER_PORT` environment variables in your environment configuration.\n\nThe `REVERB_SERVER_HOST` and `REVERB_SERVER_PORT` environment variables should not be confused with `REVERB_HOST` and `REVERB_PORT`. The former specify the host and port on which to run the Revurb server itself, while the latter pair instruct applications where to send broadcast messages. For example, in a production environment, you may route requests from your public Revurb hostname on port `443` to a Revurb server operating on `0.0.0.0:8080`. In this scenario, your environment variables would be defined as follows:\n\n```bash\nREVERB_SERVER_HOST=0.0.0.0\nREVERB_SERVER_PORT=8080\n\nREVERB_HOST=ws.laravel.com\nREVERB_PORT=443\n```\n\n<a name=\"debugging\"></a>\n### Debugging\n\nTo improve performance, Revurb does not output any debug information by default. If you would like to see the stream of data passing through your Revurb server, you may provide the `--debug` option to the `start` command:\n\n```shell\nbun run src/cli.ts start --debug\n```\n\n<a name=\"restarting\"></a>\n### Restarting\n\nSince Revurb is a long-running process, changes to your code will not be reflected without restarting the server. To restart the server, stop it using `Ctrl+C` and start it again.\n\nIf you are running Revurb with a process manager such as Supervisor or PM2, the server will be automatically restarted by the process manager after it stops.\n\n> [!NOTE]\n> Unlike Laravel Reverb, Revurb does not currently have a dedicated `restart` command. You must stop and start the server manually, or rely on your process manager to handle restarts.\n\n<a name=\"monitoring\"></a>\n## Monitoring\n\nRevurb provides a built-in health check endpoint for monitoring server status. You can access the health endpoint at:\n\n```\nGET /up\n```\n\nThis endpoint returns a JSON response indicating the server's health status:\n\n```json\n{\"health\": \"OK\"}\n```\n\nThe health check endpoint is useful for:\n- Load balancer health checks\n- Monitoring and alerting systems\n- Container orchestration health probes\n\n> [!NOTE]\n> Laravel Pulse and Telescope integrations are not currently available in the TypeScript port. These are Laravel framework-specific features that would require separate implementation.\n\n<a name=\"production\"></a>\n## Running Revurb in Production\n\nDue to the long-running nature of WebSocket servers, you may need to make some optimizations to your server and hosting environment to ensure your Revurb server can effectively handle the optimal number of connections for the resources available on your server.\n\n<a name=\"open-files\"></a>\n### Open Files\n\nEach WebSocket connection is held in memory until either the client or server disconnects. In Unix and Unix-like environments, each connection is represented by a file. However, there are often limits on the number of allowed open files at both the operating system and application level.\n\n<a name=\"operating-system\"></a>\n#### Operating System\n\nOn a Unix based operating system, you may determine the allowed number of open files using the `ulimit` command:\n\n```shell\nulimit -n\n```\n\nThis command will display the open file limits allowed for different users. You may update these values by editing the `/etc/security/limits.conf` file. For example, updating the maximum number of open files to 10,000 for the `forge` user would look like the following:\n\n```ini\n# /etc/security/limits.conf\nforge        soft  nofile  10000\nforge        hard  nofile  10000\n```\n\n<a name=\"event-loop\"></a>\n### Event Loop\n\nUnder the hood, Revurb uses Bun's native event loop to manage WebSocket connections on the server. Bun's event loop is highly optimized and can handle a large number of concurrent connections efficiently. Unlike PHP's ReactPHP which may be limited by `stream_select` (typically 1,024 open files), Bun's event loop can handle many more concurrent connections without requiring additional extensions.\n\nBun's event loop is built on top of libuv (similar to Node.js) and provides excellent performance for I/O-bound operations like WebSocket connections.\n\n<a name=\"web-server\"></a>\n### Web Server\n\nIn most cases, Revurb runs on a non web-facing port on your server. So, in order to route traffic to Revurb, you should configure a reverse proxy. Assuming Revurb is running on host `0.0.0.0` and port `8080` and your server utilizes the Nginx web server, a reverse proxy can be defined for your Revurb server using the following Nginx site configuration:\n\n```nginx\nserver {\n    ...\n\n    location / {\n        proxy_http_version 1.1;\n        proxy_set_header Host $http_host;\n        proxy_set_header Scheme $scheme;\n        proxy_set_header SERVER_PORT $server_port;\n        proxy_set_header REMOTE_ADDR $remote_addr;\n        proxy_set_header X-Forwarded-For $proxy_add_x_forwarded_for;\n        proxy_set_header Upgrade $http_upgrade;\n        proxy_set_header Connection \"Upgrade\";\n\n        proxy_pass http://0.0.0.0:8080;\n    }\n\n    ...\n}\n```\n\n> [!WARNING]\n> Revurb listens for WebSocket connections at `/app` and handles API requests at `/apps`. You should ensure the web server handling Revurb requests can serve both of these URIs.\n\nTypically, web servers are configured to limit the number of allowed connections in order to prevent overloading the server. To increase the number of allowed connections on an Nginx web server to 10,000, the `worker_rlimit_nofile` and `worker_connections` values of the `nginx.conf` file should be updated:\n\n```nginx\nuser forge;\nworker_processes auto;\npid /run/nginx.pid;\ninclude /etc/nginx/modules-enabled/*.conf;\nworker_rlimit_nofile 10000;\n\nevents {\n  worker_connections 10000;\n  multi_accept on;\n}\n```\n\nThe configuration above will allow up to 10,000 Nginx workers per process to be spawned. In addition, this configuration sets Nginx's open file limit to 10,000.\n\n<a name=\"ports\"></a>\n### Ports\n\nUnix-based operating systems typically limit the number of ports which can be opened on the server. You may see the current allowed range via the following command:\n\n```shell\ncat /proc/sys/net/ipv4/ip_local_port_range\n# 32768\t60999\n```\n\nThe output above shows the server can handle a maximum of 28,231 (60,999 - 32,768) connections since each connection requires a free port. Although we recommend [horizontal scaling](#scaling) to increase the number of allowed connections, you may increase the number of available open ports by updating the allowed port range in your server's `/etc/sysctl.conf` configuration file.\n\n<a name=\"process-management\"></a>\n### Process Management\n\nIn most cases, you should use a process manager such as Supervisor or PM2 to ensure the Revurb server is continually running. If you are using Supervisor to run Revurb, you should update the `minfds` setting of your server's `supervisor.conf` file to ensure Supervisor is able to open the files required to handle connections to your Revurb server:\n\n```ini\n[supervisord]\n...\nminfds=10000\n```\n\nExample Supervisor configuration for Revurb:\n\n```ini\n[program:revurb]\ncommand=bun run /path/to/revurb-ts/dist/cli.js start\ndirectory=/path/to/revurb-ts\nautostart=true\nautorestart=true\nuser=your-user\nredirect_stderr=true\nstdout_logfile=/var/log/revurb.log\n```\n\nFor PM2, you can create an `ecosystem.config.js` file:\n\n```javascript\nmodule.exports = {\n  apps: [{\n    name: 'revurb',\n    script: './dist/cli.js',\n    args: 'start',\n    cwd: '/path/to/revurb-ts',\n    instances: 1,\n    exec_mode: 'fork',\n    env: {\n      NODE_ENV: 'production',\n      REVERB_APP_ID: 'your-app-id',\n      REVERB_APP_KEY: 'your-app-key',\n      REVERB_APP_SECRET: 'your-app-secret',\n    },\n  }],\n};\n```\n\n<a name=\"scaling\"></a>\n### Scaling\n\nIf you need to handle more connections than a single server will allow, you may scale your Revurb server horizontally. Utilizing the publish / subscribe capabilities of Redis, Revurb is able to manage connections across multiple servers. When a message is received by one of your application's Revurb servers, the server will use Redis to publish the incoming message to all other servers.\n\nTo enable horizontal scaling, you should set the `REVERB_SCALING_ENABLED` environment variable to `true` in your environment configuration:\n\n```bash\nREVERB_SCALING_ENABLED=true\n```\n\nNext, you should configure Redis connection details. Revurb will use Redis to publish messages to all of your Revurb servers:\n\n```bash\nREDIS_HOST=127.0.0.1\nREDIS_PORT=6379\nREDIS_PASSWORD=your-redis-password\n# Or use a Redis URL\nREDIS_URL=redis://:password@127.0.0.1:6379/0\n```\n\nYou may also configure Redis in your configuration file:\n\n```typescript\nservers: {\n  reverb: {\n    host: '0.0.0.0',\n    port: 8080,\n    scaling: {\n      enabled: true,\n      channel: 'reverb',\n      server: {\n        host: '127.0.0.1',\n        port: 6379,\n        password: 'your-redis-password',\n      },\n    },\n  },\n}\n```\n\nOnce you have enabled Revurb's scaling option and configured a Redis server, you may simply invoke the `start` command on multiple servers that are able to communicate with your Redis server. These Revurb servers should be placed behind a load balancer that distributes incoming requests evenly among the servers.\n\n> [!NOTE]\n> The default Redis implementation in Revurb is a no-op mock. For production multi-server deployments requiring Redis, you must extend the `RedisClientFactory` and override `createClient()` to use a real Redis client library such as `ioredis` or `redis`.\n",

Built-in defaults\n\n<a name=\"application-credentials\"></a>\n### Application Credentials\n\nIn order to establish a connection to Revurb, a set of Revurb \"application\" credentials must be exchanged between the client and server. These credentials are configured on the server and are used to verify the request from the client. You may define these credentials using the following environment variables:\n\n```bash\nREVERB_APP_ID=my-app-id\nREVERB_APP_KEY=my-app-key\nREVERB_APP_SECRET=my-app-secret\n```\n\nAlternatively, you may configure these in a `reverb.config.ts` file:\n\n```typescript\nexport default {\n  default: 'reverb',\n  servers: {\n    reverb: {\n      host: '0.0.0.0',\n      port: 8080,\n    },\n  },\n  apps: {\n    provider: 'config',\n    apps: [\n      {\n        app_id: 'my-app-id',\n        key: 'my-app-key',\n        secret: 'my-app-secret',\n        allowed_origins: ['*'],\n      },\n    ],\n  },\n};\n```\n\n<a name=\"allowed-origins\"></a>\n### Allowed Origins\n\nYou may also define the origins from which client requests may originate by updating the value of the `allowed_origins` configuration value within the `apps` section of your configuration. Any requests from an origin not listed in your allowed origins will be rejected. You may allow all origins using `*`:\n\n```typescript\napps: {\n  provider: 'config',\n  apps: [\n    {\n      app_id: 'my-app-id',\n      allowed_origins: ['laravel.com'],\n      // ...\n    }\n  ]\n}\n```\n\nOr via environment variable:\n\n```bash\nREVERB_ALLOWED_ORIGINS=laravel.com,example.com\n```\n\n<a name=\"additional-applications\"></a>\n### Additional Applications\n\nTypically, Revurb provides a WebSocket server for a single application. However, it is possible to serve more than one application using a single Revurb installation.\n\nFor example, you may wish to maintain a single Revurb server which provides WebSocket connectivity for multiple applications. This can be achieved by defining multiple `apps` in your configuration file:\n\n```typescript\napps: {\n  provider: 'config',\n  apps: [\n    {\n      app_id: 'my-app-one',\n      key: 'app-one-key',\n      secret: 'app-one-secret',\n      // ...\n    },\n    {\n      app_id: 'my-app-two',\n      key: 'app-two-key',\n      secret: 'app-two-secret',\n      // ...\n    },\n  ],\n}\n```\n\n<a name=\"ssl\"></a>\n### SSL\n\nIn most cases, secure WebSocket connections are handled by the upstream web server (Nginx, etc.) before the request is proxied to your Revurb server.\n\nHowever, it can sometimes be useful, such as during local development, for the Revurb server to handle secure connections directly. You may configure TLS/SSL by providing certificate paths in your configuration file:\n\n```typescript\nservers: {\n  reverb: {\n    host: '0.0.0.0',\n    port: 8080,\n    options: {\n      tls: {\n        cert: '/path/to/cert.pem',\n        key: '/path/to/key.pem',\n        // Optional: passphrase for the key\n        passphrase: 'your-passphrase',\n      },\n    },\n  },\n}\n```\n\nYou may also specify a hostname when starting the server to help with certificate resolution:\n\n```shell\nbun run src/cli.ts start --hostname=\"laravel.test\"\n```\n\n<a name=\"running-server\"></a>\n## Running the Server\n\nThe Revurb server can be started using the CLI:\n\n```shell\nbun run src/cli.ts start\n```\n\nOr if you've built the project:\n\n```shell\nbun run start\n```\n\nYou can also use the built binary directly:\n\n```shell\n./dist/cli.js start\n```\n\nBy default, the Revurb server will be started at `0.0.0.0:8080`, making it accessible from all network interfaces.\n\nIf you need to specify a custom host or port, you may do so via the `--host` and `--port` options when starting the server:\n\n```shell\nbun run src/cli.ts start --host=127.0.0.1 --port=9000\n```\n\nYou can also specify a custom configuration file:\n\n```shell\nbun run src/cli.ts start --config=./custom.config.ts\n```\n\nAlternatively, you may define `REVERB_SERVER_HOST` and `REVERB_SERVER_PORT` environment variables in your environment configuration.\n\nThe `REVERB_SERVER_HOST` and `REVERB_SERVER_PORT` environment variables should not be confused with `REVERB_HOST` and `REVERB_PORT`. The former specify the host and port on which to run the Revurb server itself, while the latter pair instruct applications where to send broadcast messages. For example, in a production environment, you may route requests from your public Revurb hostname on port `443` to a Revurb server operating on `0.0.0.0:8080`. In this scenario, your environment variables would be defined as follows:\n\n```bash\nREVERB_SERVER_HOST=0.0.0.0\nREVERB_SERVER_PORT=8080\n\nREVERB_HOST=ws.laravel.com\nREVERB_PORT=443\n```\n\n<a name=\"debugging\"></a>\n### Debugging\n\nTo improve performance, Revurb does not output any debug information by default. If you would like to see the stream of data passing through your Revurb server, you may provide the `--debug` option to the `start` command:\n\n```shell\nbun run src/cli.ts start --debug\n```\n\n<a name=\"restarting\"></a>\n### Restarting\n\nSince Revurb is a long-running process, changes to your code will not be reflected without restarting the server. To restart the server, stop it using `Ctrl+C` and start it again.\n\nIf you are running Revurb with a process manager such as Supervisor or PM2, the server will be automatically restarted by the process manager after it stops.\n\n> [!NOTE]\n> Unlike Laravel Reverb, Revurb does not currently have a dedicated `restart` command. You must stop and start the server manually, or rely on your process manager to handle restarts.\n\n<a name=\"monitoring\"></a>\n## Monitoring\n\nRevurb provides a built-in health check endpoint for monitoring server status. You can access the health endpoint at:\n\n```\nGET /up\n```\n\nThis endpoint returns a JSON response indicating the server's health status:\n\n```json\n{\"health\": \"OK\"}\n```\n\nThe health check endpoint is useful for:\n- Load balancer health checks\n- Monitoring and alerting systems\n- Container orchestration health probes\n\n> [!NOTE]\n> Laravel Pulse and Telescope integrations are not currently available in the TypeScript port. These are Laravel framework-specific features that would require separate implementation.\n\n<a name=\"production\"></a>\n## Running Revurb in Production\n\nDue to the long-running nature of WebSocket servers, you may need to make some optimizations to your server and hosting environment to ensure your Revurb server can effectively handle the optimal number of connections for the resources available on your server.\n\n<a name=\"open-files\"></a>\n### Open Files\n\nEach WebSocket connection is held in memory until either the client or server disconnects. In Unix and Unix-like environments, each connection is represented by a file. However, there are often limits on the number of allowed open files at both the operating system and application level.\n\n<a name=\"operating-system\"></a>\n#### Operating System\n\nOn a Unix based operating system, you may determine the allowed number of open files using the `ulimit` command:\n\n```shell\nulimit -n\n```\n\nThis command will display the open file limits allowed for different users. You may update these values by editing the `/etc/security/limits.conf` file. For example, updating the maximum number of open files to 10,000 for the `forge` user would look like the following:\n\n```ini\n# /etc/security/limits.conf\nforge        soft  nofile  10000\nforge        hard  nofile  10000\n```\n\n<a name=\"event-loop\"></a>\n### Event Loop\n\nUnder the hood, Revurb uses Bun's native event loop to manage WebSocket connections on the server. Bun's event loop is highly optimized and can handle a large number of concurrent connections efficiently. Unlike PHP's ReactPHP which may be limited by `stream_select` (typically 1,024 open files), Bun's event loop can handle many more concurrent connections without requiring additional extensions.\n\nBun's event loop is built on top of libuv (similar to Node.js) and provides excellent performance for I/O-bound operations like WebSocket connections.\n\n<a name=\"web-server\"></a>\n### Web Server\n\nIn most cases, Revurb runs on a non web-facing port on your server. So, in order to route traffic to Revurb, you should configure a reverse proxy. Assuming Revurb is running on host `0.0.0.0` and port `8080` and your server utilizes the Nginx web server, a reverse proxy can be defined for your Revurb server using the following Nginx site configuration:\n\n```nginx\nserver {\n    ...\n\n    location / {\n        proxy_http_version 1.1;\n        proxy_set_header Host $http_host;\n        proxy_set_header Scheme $scheme;\n        proxy_set_header SERVER_PORT $server_port;\n        proxy_set_header REMOTE_ADDR $remote_addr;\n        proxy_set_header X-Forwarded-For $proxy_add_x_forwarded_for;\n        proxy_set_header Upgrade $http_upgrade;\n        proxy_set_header Connection \"Upgrade\";\n\n        proxy_pass http://0.0.0.0:8080;\n    }\n\n    ...\n}\n```\n\n> [!WARNING]\n> Revurb listens for WebSocket connections at `/app/{appKey}` (where `{appKey}` is your application key) and handles API requests at `/apps`. You should ensure the web server handling Revurb requests can serve both of these URIs.\n\nTo connect to Revurb using a WebSocket client, use the following format:\n\n```\nws://your-server:8080/app/your-app-key?protocol=7&client=js&version=8.4.0\n```\n\nOr for secure connections:\n\n```\nwss://your-server:443/app/your-app-key?protocol=7&client=js&version=8.4.0\n```\n\nReplace `your-app-key` with the actual application key configured in your Revurb server.\n\nTypically, web servers are configured to limit the number of allowed connections in order to prevent overloading the server. To increase the number of allowed connections on an Nginx web server to 10,000, the `worker_rlimit_nofile` and `worker_connections` values of the `nginx.conf` file should be updated:\n\n```nginx\nuser forge;\nworker_processes auto;\npid /run/nginx.pid;\ninclude /etc/nginx/modules-enabled/*.conf;\nworker_rlimit_nofile 10000;\n\nevents {\n  worker_connections 10000;\n  multi_accept on;\n}\n```\n\nThe configuration above will allow up to 10,000 Nginx workers per process to be spawned. In addition, this configuration sets Nginx's open file limit to 10,000.\n\n<a name=\"ports\"></a>\n### Ports\n\nUnix-based operating systems typically limit the number of ports which can be opened on the server. You may see the current allowed range via the following command:\n\n```shell\ncat /proc/sys/net/ipv4/ip_local_port_range\n# 32768\t60999\n```\n\nThe output above shows the server can handle a maximum of 28,231 (60,999 - 32,768) connections since each connection requires a free port. Although we recommend [horizontal scaling](#scaling) to increase the number of allowed connections, you may increase the number of available open ports by updating the allowed port range in your server's `/etc/sysctl.conf` configuration file.\n\n<a name=\"process-management\"></a>\n### Process Management\n\nIn most cases, you should use a process manager such as Supervisor or PM2 to ensure the Revurb server is continually running. If you are using Supervisor to run Revurb, you should update the `minfds` setting of your server's `supervisor.conf` file to ensure Supervisor is able to open the files required to handle connections to your Revurb server:\n\n```ini\n[supervisord]\n...\nminfds=10000\n```\n\nExample Supervisor configuration for Revurb:\n\n```ini\n[program:revurb]\ncommand=bun run /path/to/revurb-ts/dist/cli.js start\ndirectory=/path/to/revurb-ts\nautostart=true\nautorestart=true\nuser=your-user\nredirect_stderr=true\nstdout_logfile=/var/log/revurb.log\n```\n\nFor PM2, you can create an `ecosystem.config.js` file:\n\n```javascript\nmodule.exports = {\n  apps: [{\n    name: 'revurb',\n    script: './dist/cli.js',\n    args: 'start',\n    cwd: '/path/to/revurb-ts',\n    instances: 1,\n    exec_mode: 'fork',\n    env: {\n      NODE_ENV: 'production',\n      REVERB_APP_ID: 'your-app-id',\n      REVERB_APP_KEY: 'your-app-key',\n      REVERB_APP_SECRET: 'your-app-secret',\n    },\n  }],\n};\n```\n\n<a name=\"scaling\"></a>\n### Scaling\n\nIf you need to handle more connections than a single server will allow, you may scale your Revurb server horizontally. Utilizing the publish / subscribe capabilities of Redis, Revurb is able to manage connections across multiple servers. When a message is received by one of your application's Revurb servers, the server will use Redis to publish the incoming message to all other servers.\n\nTo enable horizontal scaling, you should set the `REVERB_SCALING_ENABLED` environment variable to `true` in your environment configuration:\n\n```bash\nREVERB_SCALING_ENABLED=true\n```\n\nNext, you should configure Redis connection details. Revurb will use Redis to publish messages to all of your Revurb servers:\n\n```bash\nREDIS_HOST=127.0.0.1\nREDIS_PORT=6379\nREDIS_PASSWORD=your-redis-password\n# Or use a Redis URL\nREDIS_URL=redis://:password@127.0.0.1:6379/0\n```\n\nYou may also configure Redis in your configuration file:\n\n```typescript\nservers: {\n  reverb: {\n    host: '0.0.0.0',\n    port: 8080,\n    scaling: {\n      enabled: true,\n      channel: 'reverb',\n      server: {\n        host: '127.0.0.1',\n        port: 6379,\n        password: 'your-redis-password',\n      },\n    },\n  },\n}\n```\n\nOnce you have enabled Revurb's scaling option and configured a Redis server, you may simply invoke the `start` command on multiple servers that are able to communicate with your Redis server. These Revurb servers should be placed behind a load balancer that distributes incoming requests evenly among the servers.\n\n> [!NOTE]\n> The default Redis implementation in Revurb is a no-op mock. For production multi-server deployments requiring Redis, you must extend the `RedisClientFactory` and override `createClient()` to use a real Redis client library such as `ioredis` or `redis`.\n"
        }
      }
    }

    /**

    export interface TlsOptions {
      /** Path to the SSL certificate file */
      cert?: string;

                "contents": "export async function loadConfig(configPath?: string): Promise<ReverbConfig> {\n\n\n  // Determine which config file to load\n  // Priority: 1. Explicit configPath, 2. ./reverb.config.ts, 3. Environment only\n  let fileToLoad = configPath;\n  if (!fileToLoad) {\n    // Check for default config file in current working directory\n    try {\n      // Use Bun's file system to check if file exists\n      const defaultConfigPath = './reverb.config.ts';\n      const file = Bun.file(defaultConfigPath);\n      if (await file.exists()) {\n        // Resolve to absolute path for reliable import\n        fileToLoad = resolve(process.cwd(), 'reverb.config.ts');\n      }\n    } catch {\n      // File doesn't exist, that's fine - we'll use env config only\n      fileToLoad = undefined;\n    }\n  }\n\n  // If a config file path is determined, try to load and merge it\n  if (fileToLoad) {\n    try {\n      // For absolute paths, use file:// protocol for ES module import\n      // For relative paths provided by user, use as-is\n      const importPath = fileToLoad.startsWith('/')\n        ? `file://${fileToLoad}`\n        : fileToLoad;\n      const fileConfig = await import(importPath);\n      const config = fileConfig.default || fileConfig;\n\n      // Build server config from environment (always needed)\n      const envServerConfig: ReverbConfig = {\n        default: defaultServer,\n        servers: {\n          [defaultServer]: loadReverbServerConfig(),\n        },\n        apps: {\n          provider: 'config',\n          apps: [],\n        },\n      };\n\n      // Try to load apps from environment, but don't fail if they're missing\n      // when a config file is provided - merge/append instead\n      let envApps: ReverbAppConfig[] = [];\n      try {\n        const envAppsConfig = loadAppsConfig();\n        envApps = envAppsConfig.apps;\n      } catch (error) {\n        // If env vars are missing, that's fine - we'll use config file apps only\n        // This allows config-driven deployments without requiring REVERB_APP_* vars\n      }\n\n      // Merge configs - env vars take precedence for servers, but append apps\n}",
